biogHist.abstract: The South Australian Cheer-Up Society was founded by Alexandrina Seager. Its object was to support the soldiers in the First and Second World Wars as well as to bring them into contact with the 'highest type of womanhood'. During world war one they visited the soldiers at camp before they embarked for the trenches and provided them with supper, concerts and conversation. In the Second World War, they started a Cheer Up Hut near the Adelaide Railway Station that had a hostel and a canteen for every day use and social functions. The hut was financed by donations from several charitable organizations including the Country Women's Association. The society was publicly acknowledged as indicative of women's capacity, support and patriotism.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: The South Australian Country Women's Association Inc. (1929 - )

archref.repository: State Library of South Australia, Mortlock Library of South Australiana
archref.abstract: Records of the Cheer Up Society Incorporated, comprise miscellaneous printed items, address presented to the CUS, stamps, badges and arm stripes, photographs, a dance program for the Jamestown branch and minutes, welcome home list, correspondence and raffle book for Kalangadoo branch. The collection also includes a published history of the Cheer Up Society during the First World War, account books mainly from the Second World War, a ledger book that covers the period between the wars, envelopes containing photographs, press cuttings from the First World War and cutting books from the second which are the most interesting parts of the collection.

physdesc.physfacet: Handwriting, typescript, newspaper cuttings, photographs, published book, scrapbooks, financial ledgers, miscellaneous items.
